<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 905, 240]]<|/det|>
0625/11 May/June 2012 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 250, 588, 292]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 313, 386, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 343, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 600, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 890, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 890, 446]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 890, 461]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 474, 555, 490]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 630, 91]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical can is rolled along the ruler shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 101, 925, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 320, 267]]<|/det|>
The can rolls over twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 594, 297]]<|/det|>
What is the circumference (distance all round) of the can?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 707, 323]]<|/det|>
**A** 13cm **B** 14cm **C** 26cm **D** 28cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 351, 96, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 598, 369]]<|/det|>
A car is moving downhill along a road at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 527, 399]]<|/det|>
Which graph is the speed/time graph for the car?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 408, 811, 750]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 776, 96, 795]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 776, 740, 794]]<|/det|>
In a race, a car travels 60 times around a 3.6km track. This takes 2.4 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 806, 434, 823]]<|/det|>
What is the average speed of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 834, 737, 852]]<|/det|>
**A** 1.5km/h **B** 90km/h **C** 144km/h **D** 216km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 452, 90]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is measured in newtons?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 215, 117]]<|/det|>
A density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 215, 142]]<|/det|>
B energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 228, 168]]<|/det|>
C pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 212, 194]]<|/det|>
D weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 224, 96, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
A geologist places a small rock on the left-hand pan of a balance. The two pans are level as shown when masses with a total weight of 23N are placed on the right-hand pan.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 416, 269]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0kg\) to be 10N.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 280, 816, 453]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 413, 482]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of the small rock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 710, 510]]<|/det|>
A \(0.023kg\) B \(2.3kg\) C \(23kg\) D \(230kg\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 542, 94, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 542, 563, 559]]<|/det|>
A stone has a volume of \(0.50 \text{cm}^3\) and a mass of \(2.0 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 390, 588]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 600, 248, 616]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 626, 240, 642]]<|/det|>
B \(1.5g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 240, 668]]<|/det|>
C \(2.5g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 679, 240, 694]]<|/det|>
D \(4.0g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 777, 91]]<|/det|>
Passengers are not allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 101, 675, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 246, 220, 263]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 275, 146, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 275, 560, 292]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to become less stable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 141, 319]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 301, 489, 318]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to slow down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 328, 567, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 567, 344]]<|/det|>
They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 146, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 354, 549, 370]]<|/det|>
They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 399, 94, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a handle with three forces, each 100 N, applied to it. The handle is free to move.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 441, 609, 616]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 497, 647]]<|/det|>
What is the effect of the forces on the handle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 659, 437, 676]]<|/det|>
<pre>A The handle will move downwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 686, 365, 702]]<|/det|>
<pre>B The handle will not move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 529, 728]]<|/det|>
<pre>C The handle will turn anticlockwise (to the left).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 738, 510, 754]]<|/det|>
<pre>D The handle will turn clockwise (to the right).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 782, 96, 800]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 782, 620, 799]]<|/det|>
In which pair of energy sources are both sources renewable?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 810, 250, 827]]<|/det|>
<pre>A oil and coal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 837, 250, 853]]<|/det|>
<pre>B oil and tidal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 863, 325, 879]]<|/det|>
<pre>C tidal and geothermal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 889, 350, 905]]<|/det|>
<pre>D tidal and nuclear fission

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
An object on a thread is swinging between X and Z, as shown in the diagram. It is moving at X and at Z.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[294, 116, 700, 350]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 745, 378]]<|/det|>
An incomplete word equation about the energy of the object is shown below.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 390, 826, 421]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy = kinetic energy + ......... energy + energy losses at X at Y at Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 645, 452]]<|/det|>
Which form of energy is needed to complete the word equation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 230, 555]]<|/det|>
A chemical B gravitational potential C internal D strain

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 585, 107, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 585, 578, 603]]<|/det|>
Which statement is explained by reference to pressure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 141, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 615, 542, 632]]<|/det|>
Objects with greater mass have greater weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 744, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 640, 744, 657]]<|/det|>
One kilogram of water occupies more volume than one kilogram of lead.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 531, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 666, 531, 683]]<|/det|>
Spikes on running-shoes sink into the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 692, 141, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 692, 606, 708]]<|/det|>
Water cooled to a low enough temperature turns to ice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a mercury manometer used to measure the pressure of gas in a Atmospheric pressure is \(76 \text{cm}\) of mercury.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 114, 803, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 339, 387, 356]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure of the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 297, 385]]<|/det|>
A 56 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 297, 411]]<|/det|>
B 68 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 297, 437]]<|/det|>
C 84 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 297, 463]]<|/det|>
D 96 cm of mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 491, 107, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 840, 507]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is observed when looking at smoke particles in air using a microscope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 562, 537]]<|/det|>
What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 490, 565]]<|/det|>
A Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 650, 591]]<|/det|>
B Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 699, 618]]<|/det|>
C Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 628, 527, 644]]<|/det|>
D Smoke particles hit the walls of the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 672, 107, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 672, 810, 688]]<|/det|>
The molecules of a substance become more closely packed and move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 701, 425, 718]]<|/det|>
What is happening to the substance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 730, 480, 746]]<|/det|>
A A gas is being heated and compressed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 756, 482, 772]]<|/det|>
B A gas is being heated and is expanding.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 782, 299, 798]]<|/det|>
C A liquid is boiling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 808, 514, 824]]<|/det|>
D A liquid is evaporating at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
Which pair contains only physical quantities that vary with temperature and so could making a thermometer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 115, 544, 133]]<|/det|>
A activity of a radioactive source, volume of a gas

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 142, 440, 159]]<|/det|>
B mass of a liquid, volume of a liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 168, 537, 185]]<|/det|>
C activity of a radioactive source, mass of a solid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 442, 211]]<|/det|>
D volume of a gas, volume of a liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 240, 107, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 908, 257]]<|/det|>
A heater supplies 80 J of energy to a block of metal. The temperature of the block rises by \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 271, 712, 288]]<|/det|>
What happens to the block of metal when its temperature falls by \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 460, 316]]<|/det|>
A Its internal energy decreases by 40 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 326, 470, 342]]<|/det|>
B Its internal energy decreases by 160 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 456, 368]]<|/det|>
C Its internal energy increases by 40 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 377, 464, 393]]<|/det|>
D Its internal energy increases by 160 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 421, 107, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole of the washer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 464, 772, 546]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 536, 576]]<|/det|>
How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 480, 604]]<|/det|>
A Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 770, 631]]<|/det|>
B Cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 492, 657]]<|/det|>
C Heat the rod and then place it in the hole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 540, 683]]<|/det|>
D Heat the washer and then place it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 711, 107, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 711, 624, 728]]<|/det|>
Why does convection take place in a liquid when it is heated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 739, 468, 755]]<|/det|>
A Liquids expand when they are heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 634, 781]]<|/det|>
B Liquids start to bubble when they get close to boiling point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 791, 592, 807]]<|/det|>
C Molecules in the liquid expand when they are heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 817, 660, 833]]<|/det|>
D Molecules near to the surface of the liquid escape into the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 809, 107]]<|/det|> Two plastic cups are placed one inside the other. Hot water is poured into the inner is put on top, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 114, 660, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 272, 349, 289]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 160, 318]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 301, 610, 318]]<|/det|> Heat loss by radiation is prevented by the small air gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 328, 144, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 544, 345]]<|/det|> No heat passes through the sides of either cup. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 714, 370]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 350, 714, 368]]<|/det|> The bench is heated by convection from the bottom of the outer cup. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 379, 560, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 378, 560, 395]]<|/det|> The lid is used to reduce heat loss by convection. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 422, 107, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 377, 440]]<|/det|> What is the unit of wavelength? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 452, 200, 467]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 452, 200, 467]]<|/det|> hertz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 478, 208, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 477, 208, 492]]<|/det|> metre <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 300, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 300, 518]]<|/det|> metre per second <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 216, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 530, 216, 544]]<|/det|> second <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 574, 107, 591]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 574, 612, 590]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes light waves and radio waves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 603, 549, 730]]<|/det|>
light wavesradio waves
Alongitudinallongitudinal
Blongitudinaltransverse
Ctransverselongitudinal
Dtransversetransverse

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 805, 107]]<|/det|> The diagram shows water waves passing through a gap in a harbour wall. The round the wall and reach a small boat in the harbour. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[302, 116, 690, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 318, 920, 351]]<|/det|> What is the name of this curving effect, and how can the gap be changed so that the waves are less likely to reach the boat? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 643, 492]]<|/det|>
name of effectchange to the gap
Adiffractionmake the gap slightly bigger
Bdiffractionmake the gap slightly smaller
Crefractionmake the gap slightly bigger
Drefractionmake the gap slightly smaller

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 500, 90]]<|/det|> The image formed by a plane mirror is upright. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 100, 780, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 517, 329]]<|/det|> What are the other characteristics of the image? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 341, 764, 485]]<|/det|>
laterally inverted (left to right)magnified (larger than the object)virtual
Anoyesyes
Byesnono
Cyesnoyes
Dyesyesno
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 514, 107, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 727, 532]]<|/det|> A student draws three rays of light from point P through a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 546, 562]]<|/det|> Each point labelled F is a principal focus of the lens. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 572, 805, 777]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 437, 810]]<|/det|> Which of the rays are drawn correctly? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 822, 141, 840]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 822, 240, 840]]<|/det|> ray Y only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 850, 240, 866]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 850, 240, 866]]<|/det|> ray Z only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 876, 285, 893]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 876, 285, 893]]<|/det|> ray X and ray Y <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 902, 285, 919]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 902, 285, 919]]<|/det|> ray X and ray Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
A girl stands at a distance from a large building. She claps her hands and a short time an echo.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 656, 135]]<|/det|>
Why is an echo produced when the sound waves hit the building?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 420, 163]]<|/det|>
A The sound waves are absorbed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 173, 420, 189]]<|/det|>
B The sound waves are diffracted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 415, 215]]<|/det|>
C The sound waves are reflected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 415, 241]]<|/det|>
D The sound waves are refracted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 269, 107, 287]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 920, 301]]<|/det|>
The diagrams represent the waves produced by four sources of sound. The scales are the same for all the diagrams.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 314, 455, 331]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 540, 90]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes a property of a magnet?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 380, 117]]<|/det|>
A It attracts ferrous materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 512, 143]]<|/det|>
B It could have only one pole (north or south).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 547, 168]]<|/det|>
C It points in a random direction when suspended.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 406, 194]]<|/det|>
D It repels non-ferrous materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 224, 107, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 604, 240]]<|/det|>
Which procedure may be used to demagnetise a steel bar?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 327, 267]]<|/det|>
A cooling it in a freezer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 391, 293]]<|/det|>
B earthing it with a copper wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 630, 320]]<|/det|>
C placing it in a solenoid carrying a large direct current (d.c.)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 448, 345]]<|/det|>
D striking it repeatedly with a hammer

A ampere

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 430, 193, 444]]<|/det|>
B ohm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 187, 470]]<|/det|>
C volt

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 482, 191, 495]]<|/det|>
D watt

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 803, 91]]<|/det|> A circuit-breaker is designed to protect a circuit which usually carries a current of 2 A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 791, 120]]<|/det|> The time taken to break the circuit depends on the current, as shown in the graph. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 131, 795, 370]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 885, 411]]<|/det|> What happens when the current in the circuit is 2A and what happens when the current 18A? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 424, 881, 553]]<|/det|>
when the current is 2Awhen the current is 18A
Athe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Bthe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit does not break
Cthe circuit does not breakthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Dthe circuit does not breakthe circuit does not break
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 581, 107, 600]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 581, 920, 613]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a coil connected to a battery and a switch. Two unmagnetised iron bars hang freely near opposite ends of the coil. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 621, 809, 785]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 593, 817]]<|/det|> What happens to the iron bars when the switch is closed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 828, 139, 846]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 828, 475, 846]]<|/det|> Both X and Y move away from the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 855, 452, 872]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 854, 453, 872]]<|/det|> Both X and Y move towards the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 882, 151, 899]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 882, 603, 899]]<|/det|> X moves towards the coil, Y moves away from the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 908, 151, 926]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 908, 603, 925]]<|/det|> Y moves towards the coil, X moves away from the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 823, 106]]<|/det|> A wire passes between the poles of a horseshoe magnet. There is a current in the direction shown, and this causes a force to act on the wire. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 115, 636, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 811, 288]]<|/det|> Three other arrangements, P, Q and R, of the wire and magnet are set up as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 298, 850, 456]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 472, 920, 504]]<|/det|> Which arrangement or arrangements will cause a force in the same direction as the original arrangement? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 516, 710, 533]]<|/det|> **A** P, Q and R **B** P and Q only **C** P only **D** R only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 561, 107, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 561, 564, 578]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a device to produce cathode rays. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 588, 747, 750]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 482, 781]]<|/det|> Which part of the device is heated and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 794, 515, 922]]<|/det|>
part heatedreason
Aanodeto emit electrons
Banodeto emit protons
Ccathodeto emit electrons
Dcathodeto emit protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 447, 90]]<|/det|> A radioactive nucleus emits a \(\beta\) -particle. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 98, 640, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 223, 688, 240]]<|/det|> What happens to the proton number (atomic number) of the nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 144, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 252, 300, 268]]<|/det|> It stays the same. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 144, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 278, 295, 295]]<|/det|> It increases by 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 300, 321]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 305, 300, 321]]<|/det|> It decreases by 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 331, 300, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 331, 300, 348]]<|/det|> It decreases by 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 375, 107, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 751, 392]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation, X, Y and Z. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[279, 400, 715, 546]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 559, 560, 576]]<|/det|> Which row in the table correctly identifies X, Y and Z? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 575, 717]]<|/det|>
XYZ
Aα-particlesβ-particlesγ-rays
Bβ-particlesα-particlesγ-rays
Cβ-particlesγ-raysα-particles
Dγ-raysα-particlesβ-particles
